metadata.case_name: Partap Singh v. State of Punjab

facts.text: Appellant was a Civil Surgeon in the employment of the State Government, granted leave preparatory to retirement.
In June 1961, Government passed orders: 1) revoking the leave, 2) recalling him to duty and placing under suspension pending inquiry, 3) ordering departmental inquiry into charges of misconduct.
Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 in Punjab High Court challenging legality of orders; dismissed on April 4, 1962; certificate granted under Art. 133(1)(c).
Appellant performed operation on Chief Minister's son Surinder Singh in April 1960 at request of Chief Minister; Surinder left care prematurely, causing displeasure.
Chief Minister and family requested undue favours for patients; appellant complied initially but later refused some.
Appellant supplied medicines to Chief Minister's wife and family, purchased himself or from hospital, supported by postal receipts 1957-1959 and tape recordings.
Appellant supplied two Singer Sewing Machines to Chief Minister's wife gratis, supported by documents Exs. C-7 to C-10 and tape recording.
Kirpa Singh, manager of automobile concern owned by Surinder, stayed at appellant's house for 7 months at instance of Chief Minister; appellant asked him to leave in April 1960.
Appellant assisted in Karnal Murder case prosecution at Chief Minister's request; prosecution failed, causing anger.
Appellant refused to give false certificate for Dr. Dhillon's salary during attachment to Chief Minister.
Complaint received October 29, 1960, alleging appellant demanded Rs. 16 from patient on July 5, 1960; led to transfer to Amritsar on December 6, 1960.
Appellant applied for leave preparatory to retirement (age 55 on June 15, 1961); sanctioned from December 18, 1960, gazetted January 27, 1961.
Blitz newspaper article January 15, 1961, alleging misconduct by Chief Minister, inspired by appellant (not named).
Appellant's wife wrote to Blitz confirming allegations in March 1961 and circulated to MPs.
Vigilance Inspector communicated to appellant on January 13, 1961, re: inquiry into Rs. 16 complaint.
Appellant joined Punjab Civil Medical Service Class I in 1947; Civil Surgeon Jullundur from April 1956.
Tape recordings produced by appellant as evidence of conversations with Chief Minister's family, admitted and considered genuine by majority.
Suspension order, revocation of leave, retention beyond superannuation June 16, 1961, notified June 10, 1961 in Gazette.
Charges related to inquiries dated October 29, 1960; January 11, 1961; April 17, 1961; some old charges revived e.g., 1957.

legal_issues.text: Whether the impugned orders of June 1961 (recalling from leave, suspension, departmental inquiry) were illegal as contrary to relevant Service Rules.
Whether the impugned orders were passed mala fide by or at the instance of the Chief Minister due to personal hostility.

petitioner_arguments.text: Impugned orders illegal as contrary to and not permitted by relevant Service Rules applicable to him.

Orders passed mala fide by Chief Minister personally hostile due to incidents: operation on son, refusal of favours/medicines/sewing machines, Kirpa Singh eviction, Karnal case failure, Dr. Dhillon certificate refusal, Blitz article.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Principles of mala fides, abuse of power, ultra vires

respondent_arguments.text: Government competent under service rules to pass impugned orders; revocation of leave, suspension, retention beyond superannuation, inquiry valid.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 8.15, 3.26(d) Punjab Civil Services Rules 1959; Art. 310 Constitution

respondent_arguments.text: No mala fides; allegations of personal grievances false; orders based on complaints and inquiries.

court_reasoning.text: Agrees mainly that orders not beyond power of Government under rules, but does not accept all interpretations; reserves on Art. 310 plea.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need to examine rules in detail due to finding on mala fides.

court_reasoning.text: Principles: Administrative orders vitiated by mala fides, fraud, corruption, improper purpose, abuse of power; can be inferred from facts; power for disciplinary action cannot be used for vengeance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Court not appellate but checks extraneous considerations or private grudge.

court_reasoning.text: Tape recordings admissible, genuine; no tampering; State had opportunity to verify.
Proved: Operation on Surinder, his premature departure causing displeasure; medicines supplied; sewing machines supplied; Kirpa Singh hosted then evicted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No denial on oath by Chief Minister or family; supported by tapes, documents.

court_reasoning.text: Timeline shows change from friendship to hostility April 1960; leave granted despite Oct 1960 complaint; Blitz article Jan 1961 triggered action.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dominant motive vengeance for Blitz disclosures, not bona fide inquiry.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent: Rules permit revocation of leave (R.8.15), suspension on leave, retention beyond superannuation (R.3.26(d)); orders effective from issue date June 3, 1961.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No mala fides proved; allegations not substantiated.

holdings.text: Impugned orders vitiated by mala fides; motivated by improper purpose of wreaking vengeance, not disciplinary action.
Orders not beyond power under rules.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bihar v. Abdul Majid
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 310 does not confer power to compel service beyond rules or superannuation.
No judgment or order stands if obtained by fraud.

precedents_cited.case_name: Municipal Council of Sydney v. Campbell
precedents_cited.relevance: Power for specified purpose cannot be used for different purposes.

precedents_cited.case_name: Marquess of Clanricarde v. Congested Districts Board

precedents_cited.relevance: Powers cannot be exercised corruptly or mala fide.

precedents_cited.case_name: Reg. v. Governors of Darlington School

precedents_cited.relevance: Power exercised beyond scope is fraud on power.

precedents_cited.case_name: Earl Fitzwilliam etc. v. Minister of T. C. Planning
General Assembly of Free Church etc. v. Overtoun
precedents_cited.relevance: Power used bona fide for conferred purposes.
State of mind inferred from facts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Khem Chand v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Suspension during period between dismissal and set aside valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bachhittar Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Not applicable to suspension orders effective from issue.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ jurisdiction; certificate for appeal; pleasure doctrine; rule-making power.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Civil Services (Punishment and Appeal) Rules, 1952
Punjab Civil Services Rules, 1959
statutes_cited.relevance: Revocation of leave; retention beyond superannuation; lien during suspension/leave.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; orders dated June 3, 1961 (revoking leave, suspension) and June 29, 1961 (inquiry) set aside as vitiated by mala fides of Chief Minister; no finding on rules violation.
outcome.costs: No order as to costs in this Court or High Court.

key_quotes.text: No judgment of a court, no order of a Minister, can be allowed to stand if it has been obtained by fraud.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes fraud/mala fides vitiates administrative orders.

key_quotes.text: The Court is not an appellate forum where the correctness of an order of Government could be canvassed... The only question which could be considered by the Court is whether the authority... has paid attention to... matters wholly extraneous... or whether the proceedings have been initiated mala fide for satisfying a private or personal grudge.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of judicial review for mala fides.

key_quotes.text: Leave cannot be claimed as of right. When the exigencies of the public services so require, discretion to refuse or revoke leave of any description is reserved to the authority empowered to grant it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Upholds power to revoke leave under rules.
